overall_score_comment: Three points because at least it rhymes better than a drunk opera singer's suicide note written during a thunderstorm.
the_roast:
Let me get this straight: Freddie opens with four consecutive questions like he's having an existential crisis at a philosophy 101 lecture, then immediately declares himself a 'poor boy' who needs no sympathy WHILE BEGGING FOR SYMPATHY FOR THE ENTIRE SONG. Pick a lane, mate. You can't be 'easy come, easy go' and then spend six minutes having a complete meltdown because 'Mama, ooo.' This isn't emotional depth, it's emotional whiplash set to a piano.

The murder confession section reads like a teenager's creative writing assignment where they discovered the thesaurus but not narrative coherence. 'Mama, just killed a man / Put a gun against his head / Pulled my trigger, now he's dead' – congratulations, you've managed to make homicide sound as exciting as reading assembly instructions. And the kicker? 'Life had just begun, but now I've gone and thrown it all away' – yeah, that tends to happen when you MURDER SOMEONE. Real shocking development there, Sherlock.

Then we barrel headfirst into what I can only describe as a fever dream written by someone who fell asleep during both an opera AND a Renaissance fair. 'Scaramouch, scaramouch will you do the fandango'? Excuse me? We went from murder confession to randomly summoning commedia dell'arte characters and demanding they perform Spanish dances. And screaming 'Galileo' five times doesn't make you cultured, it makes you sound like you're having a stroke at a planetarium. Throw in some 'Bismillah' (because nothing says authentic Arabic prayer like using it to beg imaginary court figures to let you go), a random 'Beelzebub' name-drop, and a 'mama mia' because apparently we're doing ALL the languages now, and you've got yourself a linguistic trash fire.

The grand finale? After all this operatic chaos, murder mystery, and religious confusion, we end with 'Nothing really matters' repeated like a depressed fortune cookie. Oh, NOW nothing matters? You just spent five minutes acting like EVERYTHING matters – your mama, your trial, your soul, Galileo's opinion – but sure, let's just wrap it up with nihilism and call it deep. This song is what happens when you let a drama student write their own obituary while high on their own importance.

cliche_counter.cliche: Is this real life or fantasy?
cliche_counter.quip: No, it's a Morpheus quote before The Matrix existed, and it's been the caption on every pseudo-deep Instagram post since 1975.
The 'I told my mom I did something bad' trope, except most people confess to breaking a vase, not committing felony murder.
The battle cry of every nihilistic teenager who just discovered existentialism and thinks they're the first person to ever feel feelings.
Said twice because apparently the first time we didn't understand that you have the emotional commitment of a goldfish.

cliche_counter.cliche: Poor boy from a poor family
cliche_counter.quip: Playing the poverty card while literally performing the most expensive-sounding operatic section in rock history. Pick a tax bracket.

cliche_counter.cliche: I don't want to die / wish I'd never been born
cliche_counter.quip: Can't decide between fearing death or regretting birth? That's not depth, that's just indecisive angst.

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Scaramouch, scaramouch will you do the fandango / Thunderbolt and lightning - very very frightening me
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Random word salad masquerading as artistic vision; throwing Italian stock characters, Spanish dances, and weather phenomena into a blender and calling it poetry
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Forced to explain the narrative coherence of this section to a panel of actual opera composers while they silently judge you

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Gallileo, Gallileo, Gallileo, Gallileo, Gallileo Figaro - magnifico
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Screaming a scientist's name five times then mashing it together with an opera character because you saw both words in a textbook once
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must take a remedial course in both astronomy AND opera, then write a 500-word essay on why this makes no goddamn sense

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Bismillah! No - we will not let you go
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Appropriating Arabic religious phrases for a rock opera trial scene like it's just a fun exotic word you learned
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Apologize to every Arabic speaker who had to explain to confused fans that no, this isn't how Islamic prayer works

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: So you think you can stone me and spit in my eye / So you think you can love me and leave me to die
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Biblical punishment imagery awkwardly shoved next to relationship drama; mixing metaphors like a drunk bartender
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must choose one (1) thematic lane and stay in it for at least thirty consecutive seconds

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Nothing really matters - nothing really matters to me / Anyway the wind blows
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Ending your dramatic magnum opus with the lyrical equivalent of a shrug emoji
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: After six minutes of acting like EVERYTHING matters, must write a sincere apology for this cop-out ending

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a deep metaphor about Schrödinger's cat, where the protagonist exists in a quantum superposition between being a murderer, an opera character, and a weather vane, all while having an Oedipus complex. The repeated invocation of Galileo represents man's futile attempt to use science to escape the gravitational pull of mommy issues. Or, you know, it's just what happens when you write lyrics while playing Mad Libs with a history textbook.
final_verdict: Bohemian Rhapsody is what you get when you give someone with main character syndrome a thesaurus, a history book, and six minutes to create the most elaborate excuse for missing curfew ever written. It's not a song, it's a cry for help disguised as a opera disguised as a rock ballad disguised as whatever the hell that middle section was supposed to be.
title: Bohemian Rhapsody
